content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue, consistent with a lymph node dissection. I can identify approximately 10-12 distinct nodular structures that appear to be lymph nodes. They vary in size and staining pattern. Most are densely basophilic (purple), representing lymphoid tissue, while some have paler, more eosinophilic (pink) areas which could represent germinal centers, fatty infiltration, or, critically for this case, metastatic tumor deposits. The goal is to screen all these nodes for metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my standard procedure is to systematically examine every piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is one of these potential lymph nodes, located on the far left of the slide. I am zooming in on this specific nodule, which is the 1st lymph node I am examining from the left, to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification. Even small nodes must be carefully checked for micrometastases. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed over one of the larger, more prominent lymph nodes in the upper portion of the slide. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all tissue fragments. Examining the interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fat is important, as is evaluating the internal architecture of the node itself for any abnormal cell populations. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A pathologist must examine every lymph node submitted to accurately stage the cancer. I am zooming into this specific area, which is one of the centrally located, smaller lymph nodes (approximately the 5th distinct node from the top), because its low-power architecture is abnormal. Unlike a normal or reactively enlarged lymph node, this node has a peculiar 'punched-out' or fenestrated appearance, with islands of basophilic tissue separated by empty-looking or pale pink spaces. This architectural disruption is highly suspicious for metastatic involvement, warranting a closer look. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify any metastatic tumor deposits in the lymph nodes. It is crucial to examine every single piece of tissue that could be a lymph node, regardless of its size or shape. The area highlighted by the green box contains one of the smaller, more fragmented pieces of lymphoid tissue located at the bottom of the slide. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic, comprehensive review of all submitted tissue to ensure no potential site of metastasis is missed. This is the first lymph node from the bottom left that I am evaluating. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all the lymph nodes present on the slide. This particular lymph node, one of the central ones, appears to have its normal architecture at least partially replaced. Even at low power, there seem to be pale, irregular areas within the lymphoid tissue, which is a key feature to investigate for metastatic carcinoma, especially mucinous types. The goal is to examine the interface between the native lymphoid tissue and the potential metastatic deposit at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for this slide is to examine every lymph node for metastatic cancer. The green box highlights a portion of the lymph node located at the bottom right of the slide. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic, piece-by-piece evaluation. The dense cellularity of this node, appearing dark purple at low power, requires high-magnification assessment to determine the nature of the cells. I need to differentiate between a reactive lymphoid population and infiltration by malignant tumor cells, which can also appear as dense, dark sheets. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every single lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box highlights one of the lymph nodes situated on the far right of the slide. I would systematically review each node, and this is simply one of them in the sequence. This particular node appears mostly solid and dark, suggesting that its normal architecture might be effaced, which is a suspicious feature for metastatic replacement. Therefore, I am zooming in to assess its cellular composition and architecture at a higher magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal here is to identify any lymph node metastasis, which is critical for staging the colorectal cancer. I would systematically examine every lymph node. I zoomed into this specific area on the right because this lymph node, like several others, exhibits an abnormal architecture at low power. Instead of a uniform population of lymphocytes, there are paler, more eosinophilic areas mixed with the basophilic lymphoid tissue. This heterogeneity is highly suspicious for replacement of the normal lymph node parenchyma by metastatic tumor glands, which often appear more pink. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a portion of a lymph node characterized by a dense, well-circumscribed aggregate of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. This is consistent with normal lymphoid tissue, possibly the cortex of the node. Surrounding this lymphoid tissue is perinodal fibro-adipose tissue. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or extensive necrosis that would indicate metastatic carcinoma in this specific field of view. My impression of this area is a benign lymph node fragment. I would continue to scan the rest of this tissue fragment before moving to the next node.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the architecture of a lymph node. There are dense aggregates of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes, forming lymphoid follicles. This node is surrounded by mature adipose tissue (fat). I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells within the lymphoid tissue. The overall appearance is that of a benign, reactive lymph node. My impression is that this particular lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node (cortex, paracortex, medulla, sinuses) is completely effaced. It is replaced by a striking pattern of anastomosing cords and islands of dark, basophilic cells, creating a cribriform or labyrinthine appearance. The intervening spaces contain pale, eosinophilic, proteinaceous material and some hemorrhage. The basophilic cells are predominantly lymphocytes, but they are reacting to and outlining spaces that are likely occupied by metastatic carcinoma. This pattern, sometimes described as tumor cells in dilated sinuses or a micropapillary pattern of metastasis, is highly indicative of a positive lymph node. My impression is that this is a lymph node extensively involved by metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a portion of a lymph node. There is a dense aggregate of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes. This lymphoid tissue appears organized and is located at the periphery of the tissue fragment, consistent with the cortex of a lymph node. Surrounding the lymphoid tissue is a thin fibrous capsule, adipose tissue (large clear spaces), and some small blood vessels. I do not see any atypical cells, glandular structures, or clusters of malignant epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a portion of a benign, reactive lymph node with no evidence of cancer.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, the normal lymph node architecture is largely effaced. There are vast, irregular pools of pale pink, acellular-appearing material, which is characteristic of extracellular mucin. Within these mucin pools, there are floating clusters and small glandular arrangements of atypical epithelial cells. The native lymphoid tissue, composed of small dark lymphocytes, is pushed to the periphery and dissects between the mucin lakes. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are producing copious amounts of extracellular mucin, which has replaced the majority of the lymphoid parenchyma.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. There are interspersed small, irregular spaces lined by endothelial cells, representing preserved but compressed lymph node sinuses. Some contain pale-staining histiocytes. Importantly, there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma; I do not see atypical glands, large pleomorphic epithelial cells with prominent nucleoli, or a desmoplastic stromal response. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, and this specific area is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense, monotonous sheet of small, dark, round cells. The normal architecture of a lymph node, which includes distinct follicles with germinal centers and open sinuses, is completely effaced. The tissue is packed with these cells. At the periphery, there is a hint of a capsule and a subcapsular sinus, but even these seem to be infiltrated. While I do not see classic, well-formed glands or large pleomorphic epithelial cells typical of some colorectal adenocarcinomas, the complete architectural effacement by a monotonous population of cells is highly abnormal. My impression is that this is a lymph node completely replaced by metastatic carcinoma, likely a poorly differentiated type. I would classify this as a positive lymph node. To confirm the epithelial nature of these cells, I would order immunohistochemical stains for cytokeratins (e.g., AE1/AE3, CAM5.2).
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the suspicion of metastasis is confirmed. The left and upper portion of the image shows lymph node parenchyma that is extensively infiltrated by malignant glands. These are irregular, cribriform (sieve-like) and back-to-back glandular structures, which are hallmarks of metastatic adenocarcinoma from a colorectal primary. The tumor cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This tumor deposit is adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue on the right. My impression is definitive for metastatic adenocarcinoma involving this lymph node, making it a positive node.
